Message.Title: Dividend and price projections
Message.Msg: I have BAC in my portfolio and thus I am most interested in the long arrange up her objections for dividend i and share price. I have thus come up with a simplistic model which allows me to project what might happen in 2013 and 2014. Starting off in 2007, the year before the crash, we had in EPS of $4.40 and a dividend of $2.40 which heals a 54% payout ratio – numbers are not exact to the penny but close. For the year 2013 EPS projections are $.94 – this yields a dividend of about $.50. Management has often buyback approximately $5 billion in common stock and preferred stock. Given 10.8 million shares outstanding and 5 billion in buyback – this equates to $.46 per share. Thus the correlation is quite close. Given a historical PE of 13 this indicates a share price of about $12.22. The stock is currently at $13.70 in the increase above the model is most likely due to increases in EPS on a quarterly basis. For the year 2014 EPS is projected at 1.29 – at a 54% payout this would indicate a $.70 dividend on a yearly basis. Is my feeling that management will start paying an increased dividend in 2014 starting off with perhaps $.05-$.10 per quarter in exiting the year at the rate of $.15-$.20 per quarter. Of course management matricide to continue the share buyback program and limit the dividend in this would have a positive effect on share price. A combination of the two is always possible. Turning to share price the model indicates a $17 share price given no catastrophic situations in the economy or the market. Based on this given accelerating EPS on a quarterly basis I could see BAC exiting 2014 in the $18-$20 range. Beyond 2014 you can do the math based upon the room EPS projections. However, EPS two or three years out could get two dollars share yielding roughly a dividend of one dollar on an annual basis in share price in the order of 26 $28 – not bad I would appreciate any feedback on my methodology your views of the future – good luck to all.

Message.Msg: The world is changing. Be careful you don't miss it. Yes, there are many dangers lurking out there, but failing to pay attention to what's going on around you could be detrimental to your financial future. The US will soon be a major oil and gas exporter rather than importer despite all the government efforts to thwart market forces. In addition many companies are bringing production back to the US because energy remains cheaper here and, believe it or not, wage differentials are decreasing due to rising wages overseas. Even slight moves in these large expenses can turn companies back home. While government and Fed Reserve actions could still ruin things, the markets are doing what they have always done, they are adjusting, they are adapting, and the US currently appears it will be the major benefactor of those changes taking place.

Topic.Title: Dividend and price projections

Message.Msg: Your analysis is steeply flawed. First forget the Analyst Estimates those are the people who said to sell at $6 while I was buying. Our eps will probably be $1.10 for 2013 (given release of bad debt reserves). Also, we did not have Merrill Lynch before (as your historical model only incorporates a bank and not a brokerage firm) which is faster growing than a bank and deserves a higher multiple. Even Meredith Whitney, famous analyst, who only recently came on board has stated BAC at least $22 by Dec/2014. I expect $16-$18 for end of 2013. Then, $24-$25 for 2014 year end. In 2-3 years after that expect $50, YES $50!!! Even Bove, another famous bank analyst, said it should sell for up to 2.5 BV during good times. That he thinks banks are a buy at 1.5 book value and sell at 2.5 book value. Well BAC will have a Book Value of $24 at the end of 2015. Therefore $24 X 2 book value is $48 for fair value for 2015 year end. Do not think it cannot happen. All is my opinion.

Topic.Title: Dividend and price projections

Message.Msg: That all, of course, depends on Fed approval, as well as other regulatory issues still outstanding. My biggest concern for the 2014-2015 term would be how fast and how far interest rates rise. Slow rising rates shouldn't be a problem, but fast rising rates would severely hamper the banks due to all the older, lower rate loans they currently carry on the books. It takes time to replace them with higher rate loans and in the meantime the banks will be paying higher rates on deposits and funds they have to borrow. This will squeeze the NIM, not widen it. On a side note, I'd like them to focus on buying back more shares before they increase the dividend significantly. When necessary, buybacks are easy to slow down or put on hold, but dividends carry a lot of emotional baggage if they get raised then have to be lowered again.

Topic.Title: Dividend and price projections

Message.Msg: You may also want to plug into your metrics ROA. Historically it has been rather stable at around 1.16% if you throw out a few excessive highs and lows. But you should temper your projections by the unknown added regulatory burdens on the big banks and a changing interest rate environment which could either expand or contract net interest margins. And rising rates means higher loan volume but it also means declining values on the mortgage and debt portfolios. All in all, the market has BAC priced about right and long term the trend is up.

Message.Msg: 90% of day traders go bust within a year. Most don't want to actually work for a living. They enjoy getting up late, finishing by 4pm and "being their own boss". It's fiction the idea that there are a lot of people out there doing it. Short capital gains tax rate is also a killer.

Topic.Title: Does anyone here trade for a living? Can it be done?

Message.Msg: I have been doing it only since Dec 21st due to layoff in contract mechanical design work, not by choice. I had invested approx. 83K in BAC stock at average of 8.03 share 10,500ish shares. I decided to take long term gaines on stock I held over one year 80% of holdings (I have carry over loss from a few years back of 35K) and took 28K profit. I then started trading and sold all bac remaining 20% at short term gain and currently as of today have a taken profits of 62,990.00. But I feel I am gambling more so than investing and the market is working in my favor the past 6 months. I ALSO DO NOT WATCH ANY CNBC OR ANY OTHER. I stay glued to my lap top from 6:30 till 1:30 (I am in WA) each day and read any and all business news I can stand. I am supposed to take a job in Portland, OR on Monday, I live north of Seattle and it pays low for my industry is short term temporary and with added living expense I am wanting to back out and keep trading.....but feel I need to take best thing available tilll something else comes along.

Topic.Title: Does anyone here trade for a living? Can it be done?

Message.Msg: short term capital tax is at same rate as any working earnings are taxed....so if you work you get taxed and if you trade at home in your underwear you get the same tax rate.....I want to pay a small furtune in taxes!

Topic.Title: Does anyone here trade for a living? Can it be done?

Message.Msg: It's possible if you have enough cash to start. I would suggest options. I don't trade for a living, but I make about 3-4 option trades per week. My goal is to make a 30-75% per trade. Also would like to be profitable on 2 out of 3 trades I do. I study about 30-40 stocks at any given time and watch their price patterns. Buy low and sell when the option gets a little higher. Not hard to make 30% per trade. Some options trades I will do 75-100% return. Having a smartphone allows me to do this and stay on top of everything.

Topic.Title: Today we supposed to hear how the judged ruled on the 8.5 billion agreement

Message.Msg: Same issue from different angles. AIG was suing the Fed because the Fed was saying AIG couldn't sue BAC, but since the judge ruled a bit ago that the suit against BAC could continue, AIG has decided to drop the suit against the Feds, at least for now. However, this isn't the same issue that was supposed to have the hearing today. That issue is about the settlement that BAC had brokered with BNY Mellon as trustee for a bunch of mbs investors. It all gets a bit confusing after a while.

Topic.Title: Dividend and price projections

Message.Msg: The FED had been firm that they want to see banks retain more capital, book it into safer vehicles, and pay under 30% of earnings in dividends. The uptrend on BAC from last year has legs but this is not a stock rocketing to old levels. It will take several years to whittle 11B share float back to around 6B again. There will continue to be dip buying opportunities along the way.
